contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Tolkien character |image_character = |image_caption = |character_name = Voronwë |character_alias = 'The Steadfast' |character_title = |character_race = Elf |character_culture = Noldor |character_birth = |character_death = |character_departure = |character_realm = Goldolin |Book(s) = ''The Silmarillion'' }} In [[Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Silmarillion]]'', '''Voronwë''' (pronounced {{IPA-art|vɔˈrɔnwɛ|}}) was a [[Noldor]]in [[Elf (Middle-earth)|Elf]] from [[Gondolin]]. His name is [[Quenya]] in origin, meaning 'steadfast one' (the [[Sindarin]] form is '''Bronwë'''). The name ''Voronwë'' also appears as an ''[[epessë]]'' (honorary title) of various other characters, for example [[Mardil Voronwë]]. [[Image:Ulmo saves Voronwe.jpg|right|thumb|'''Ulmo and Voronwë'''<br>illustration by Tom Loback]] Voronwë was relatively young according to the measure of the Elves, having been born in [[Middle-earth]] (and specifically in [[Nevrast]]) instead of [[Valinor]]. His father was '''Aranwë''', a Noldo, but his mother was of the [[Sindar]]in Elves of the [[Falas]], and kinswoman of [[Círdan]]. Voronwë called himself "of the House of [[Fingolfin]]", which in this case likely means a follower of that house, rather than a relationship of blood, although some [[Tolkien fandom|Tolkien fans]] have proposed his descent from [[Daughters of Finwë|Irimë]], sister of Fingolfin. Voronwë was among those Gondolindrim who were sent by [[Turgon]] to the [[Bay of Balar]] after the [[Nírnaeth Arnoediad|Battle of Unnumbered Tears]]. Their errand was to seek the help of Círdan in shipbuilding so that they would be able to reach Valinor and deliver the Elves' prayer for aid to the [[Vala (Middle-earth)|Lords of the West]]. But he tarried on the way, wandering enchanted in the [[Nan-tathren|Willow-meads of Nan-tathren]]. Thus Voronwë came last of the messengers to Círdan, when six out of seven ships built at Turgon's asking had sailed into the West. He was the captain of the last, and the greatest, ship that for seven years journeyed across [[Belegaer]], seeking a path into the West through "loathing, and loneliness, and madness; terror of wind and tumult, and silence, and shadows where all hope is lost and all living shapes pass away".<ref>{{ME-ref|UT|Of Tuor and his Coming to Gondolin, p. 36}}</ref> Still, the [[Doom of the Valar]] worked against them, and the West was still shut. In despair they turned back, but when already within the sight of [[Middle-earth|Mortal Lands]], their ship was caught in a great storm and drowned. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Tuor and Voronwë See Túrin at the Pools of Ivrin by Ted Nasmith.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Tuor and Voronwë See Túrin at the Pools of Ivrin (by [[Ted Nasmith]])]] --> However, Voronwë was spared, alone of all sent by Turgon and Círdan. He was saved by [[Ulmo]] and cast ashore at [[Vinyamar]], the land of his birth. There he was greeted by [[Tuor]] of the [[House of Hador|Third House of Men]], who passed him Ulmo's bidding to guide Tuor to Gondolin. Reluctantly, Voronwë obeyed, remembering the prophecies of old. For more than a month they journeyed eastward along the southern slopes of [[Ered Wethrin]] to the entrance into the Hidden City, in spite of the Doom of the Valar and the Malice of the [[Morgoth|Enemy]], protected by Ulmo's power. On the road they met Tuor's first cousin [[Túrin Turambar]] by the ruins of [[Eithel Ivrin]] without recognizing him. Voronwë was admitted to Gondolin as a former inhabitant; Tuor was at first held captive, but then released and was able to pass to Turgon Ulmo's warnings. There is no further mention of Voronwë in the canon works, except a statement where it is implied that he survived the [[Fall of Gondolin]].<ref>Unfinished Tales: Of Tuor and his Coming to Gondolin, p. 33 and note 12.</ref> Other accounts suggest that later he sailed into the West with Tuor and [[Idril]].<ref>{{ME-ref|WotJ|The Tale of Years, p. 352, 354}}</ref> == References == {{Portal|Middle-earth}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.tednasmith.com/silmarillion/TN-Tuor_and_Voronwe_See_Turin.html ''Tuor and Voronwë See Túrin at the Pool of Ivrin''] as illustrated by [[Ted Nasmith]] {{Middle-earth}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Voronwe}} [[Category:Characters in The Silmarillion]] [[Category:Fictional captains]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1977]] [[Category:High Elves]] [[Category:Noldor]] [[fr:Voronwë]] [[pl:Lista Calaquendich#Voronwë]]
